In today’s world, who couldn’t benefit from additional internet speed? Websites, software, and files continue to grow larger, but unfortunately, technology budgets haven’t kept pace. Imagine doubling your internet speed without increasing your current expenses – an appealing proposition, wouldn’t you agree?
It might sound illogical to suggest that doubling your internet speed wouldn’t cost more, especially since internet providers aren’t known for giving things away for free. The secret lies in adopting newer, more cost-effective technology instead of simply replacing your existing service with an identical one from another provider.
One way to double your internet speed with your current or a new provider, while retaining your T1 line service, is to order a second T1 line and “bond” it with your existing line. Bonding combines two lines to function as a single, faster line. A single T1 line provides 1.5 Mbps, so bonding two lines results in a speed of 3 Mbps. However, there are a couple of limitations. First, both T1 lines must be from the same provider, either your current one or a new one for both lines. Second, your monthly cost will double since you’re now paying for two lines. While you might find a different vendor offering lower prices for the same service, this alone likely won’t get you 3 Mbps for the price of 1.5 Mbps.
Instead of simply doubling down on T1 lines, consider switching to Ethernet over Copper. Both are dependable business-grade internet services with dedicated bandwidth. They can also be managed services, where the provider handles all the necessary equipment at your location to connect to their lines and your network. Another similarity between bonded T1 lines and Ethernet over Copper is that they both utilize the existing copper telephone wires already installed in your building. Although the signal types differ between T1 and Ethernet lines, they function the same way from a user’s perspective. The key difference lies in the cost. Ethernet over Copper, being a newer technology, utilizes the bandwidth capacity of copper lines more effectively. As a result, its pricing is very competitive, currently about half the cost of two bonded T1 lines. This means you could obtain a 3 Mbps Ethernet over Copper service for the same price as a 1.5 Mbps T1 service. A few other distinctions exist as well. T1 lines can only be upgraded in increments of 1.5 Mbps per bonded line. Ethernet, on the other hand, offers more flexibility, with bandwidth options ranging from 1 Mbps up to 10 Gbps, though higher speeds necessitate fiber optic cables. However, unlike T1, Ethernet over Copper has limited availability, primarily found in larger cities and suburbs rather than rural areas.
Interested in doubling your internet speed without increasing your costs? Check pricing and availability for 3 x 3 Mbps Ethernet over Copper or other Ethernet bandwidth services to discover potential savings in your area.
title: 3x3 Mbps Ethernet Doubles Your Bandwidth

For the past decade, small and medium businesses have relied on T1 lines as their primary commercial telecom solution. However, a new competitor called 2x2 Ethernet, recently introduced by major nationwide carrier MegaPath, is emerging to challenge the long-standing T1. Let’s explore what 2x2 Ethernet offers.
It might seem surprising that T1 lines would face competition, considering their 50-year history and widespread adoption. As the first widely available broadband digital connection for businesses, T1 emerged from telephone company research. Initially used to connect calls between switching centers, it later became commercially available. Leveraging repeater technology and unshielded twisted pair telco wires, T1 became the leading technology for digital phone lines, point-to-point connections, and dedicated broadband access.
Ethernet, on the other hand, originated in the computer industry and has become the dominant networking technology for local area networks (LANs). While traditionally considered a LAN technology, unlike the WAN-focused T1, Ethernet has steadily expanded into metropolitan and wide area networks in recent years. Now, it’s poised to replace T1 lines altogether. But why?
Bandwidth is a key factor. T1 lines offer a fixed, symmetrical bandwidth of 1.5 Mbps for both uploads and downloads. Ethernet, however, supports various speeds over copper and fiber optic cables. MegaPath’s 2x2 Ethernet provides 2 Mbps for both uploads and downloads, a modest but notable improvement over T1. Beyond the 33% capacity increase, 2x2 Ethernet offers simple integration. Connecting from WAN to LAN is as easy as using a standard Ethernet connector, eliminating the need for additional CSU/DSU interface circuitry required by T1 lines.
The most compelling aspect of MegaPath’s 2x2 Ethernet is its affordability compared to T1 lines. While Ethernet has often boasted lower per-Mbps costs than traditional telecom services, particularly at higher bandwidths, this 2 Mbps service undercuts the price of a 1.5 Mbps service. Additionally, customers can choose between data-only or voice and data configurations. Opting for at least five lines of digital, analog, or SIP trunking telephone service further reduces the cost of a 2x2 Ethernet line. These factors suggest that the era of T1 dominance might be coming to an end.
MegaPath has addressed availability concerns by offering Ethernet over Copper connections through 1,900 central offices across the country, covering an estimated 90% of businesses, both small and large. MegaPath itself is a “super CLEC” (Competitive Local Exchange Carrier), formed by merging MegaPath, Covad, and Speakeasy, all significant carriers in their own right.
If your business needs new connectivity or you’re simply seeking a better deal on your current T1 line service, it’s worth exploring your options. Older T1 contracts could be costing you double what they should. Consider a quick pricing and availability inquiry for Ethernet over Copper services to be sure. Higher bandwidth options are also available for more demanding applications.
title: 2x2 Ethernet Takes on T-1

Wireless broadband is becoming increasingly popular and poised to replace many traditional wireline technologies thanks to its portability and mobility. However, the limited availability and speed of wireless connections have hindered its wider adoption and application. The emergence of 4G wireless technology offers a promising solution.
](http://www.cellphoneplansfinder.com/)
While 4G wireless lacks a precise definition, it generally refers to bandwidth comparable to cable broadband or Ethernet over copper business connections. With its high speed and broad coverage, 4G has the potential to serve both desktop and mobile devices.
Some might consider WiFi a 4G technology due to its bandwidth capabilities. However, WiFi’s short-range nature limits its use to specific locations like homes, offices, or public spaces. Unlike cellular networks, WiFi connections are not designed for continuous use while on the move and function more like a personal area network.
Cellular phone service relies on higher-powered wireless technologies like 2G and 3G. These systems utilize networks of fixed transmitters and receivers arranged in cells to provide coverage across a wide area. The key to enabling seamless connectivity as users move between cells lies in effectively coordinating the handoff of the wireless connection.
Currently, 3G is the most prevalent wireless technology, providing bandwidth comparable to T1 lines and basic DSL, averaging around 1.5 Mbps in urban areas. While this speed is sufficient for many mobile activities like web browsing, email, and watching short videos, 3G faces limitations in both speed and bandwidth availability.
Sharing channels with cellular voice traffic on existing towers puts a strain on 3G networks, which were initially designed for voice calls. This shared bandwidth, coupled with the higher data demands of internet traffic, leads to carriers imposing data caps.
There are two main approaches to 4G wireless. Cell phone companies view it as an upgrade to their existing 3G infrastructure. The two dominant cellular systems, CDMA (used by Verizon and Sprint) and GSM (used by AT&T and T-Mobile), have adopted different paths to 4G.
AT&T and T-Mobile have enhanced their 3G networks to HSPA+, offering speeds up to 6-8 Mbps. Verizon has implemented LTE, a 4G technology providing download speeds of 5-12 Mbps. Meanwhile, Sprint utilizes WiMAX, another 4G technology, delivering speeds between 3-6 Mbps.
Looking ahead, 4G is expected to converge around two technologies: LTE and WiMAX. Considered a potential universal standard, LTE is widely discussed. WiMAX, predating LTE, is already deployed globally. Both technologies offer upgrade paths capable of boosting download speeds to over 100 Mbps and even 1000 Mbps, rivaling fiber optic speeds. This ensures the longevity of 4G wireless technology.
Furthermore, 4G is increasingly utilizing lower frequency bands that can penetrate buildings more effectively. These bands, repurposed from UHF TV channels through a federal auction, offer greater flexibility. For instance, Clear provides 4G fixed and mobile wireless service, including a telephone option, using WiMAX in over 80 cities across the nation, currently offering unlimited broadband plans.

title: 4G Wireless Broadband Options

The race for 4G dominance is about to start, even though 3G deployment is still underway. Major carriers like AT&T, Verizon, and Sprint have upgraded most of their towers in populated areas, and 3G devices are readily available. However, the focus is shifting to 4G due to the increasing demand for bandwidth from sophisticated mobile applications and the ongoing competition among carriers.
The value of 4G lies in its potential to enable future advancements rather than just meeting current needs. Similar to the space race or the transcontinental railroad, the development of 4G is driven by a forward-thinking approach.
The 3G competition revolves around two incompatible standards: EVDO for CDMA networks (Verizon, Alltel, Sprint) and UMTS broadband (AT&T, T-Mobile, and international carriers) for GSM networks.
Similarly, the 4G competition is also split between two standards: WiMAX, a global standard for fixed and mobile broadband, and LTE, which has garnered support from both Verizon and AT&T. While Sprint and fixed wireless provider Clearwire are backing WiMAX, Verizon and AT&T are adopting LTE.
Unlike the transition from analog to digital TV, 3G and 4G will coexist for a significant period. This coexistence is possible because WiMAX operates on the 2.5 GHz band using Sprint and Clearwire’s combined channel licenses, while Verizon and AT&T will utilize the 700 MHz spectrum previously used for analog TV broadcasting.
The actual bandwidth provided by 4G remains a question. Although initial claims for WiMAX touted a range of 30 miles and speeds of 30-70 Mbps, real-world performance has been lower. Sprint’s Xohm service in Baltimore offered 2-4 Mbps, and Clearwire’s Clear 4G service in Portland, OR, provides 4-6 Mbps.
While LTE is not yet deployed, tests have shown peak data rates of 60-80 Mbps. Verizon estimates average LTE speeds around 8 Mbps, but this could be a conservative figure. Both LTE and WiMAX have the potential to scale up and offer faster speeds as demand and competition increase.
Currently, WiMAX has a head start in the 4G race with systems already commercially available. However, Verizon’s LTE operates on lower frequencies, potentially enabling better building penetration. Verizon plans to have LTE in two markets by the end of the year and expand to 25-30 markets in 2010, a pace similar to WiMAX’s projected rollout.
By 2011 or 2012, 4G is expected to reach a tipping point, offering both mobile and fixed location services. This will create competition for DSL and cable internet providers while also empowering smartphones and netbooks. Video streaming, cloud computing, and interactive applications are anticipated to be the driving forces behind 4G adoption, taking advantage of the increased bandwidth.
title: 4G Wireless Broadband Wars This Year

Reliable and fast business internet access is crucial for customer interaction and order processing. While you aim for a stable connection with sufficient bandwidth, you also need a budget-friendly option. Let’s explore ways to incrementally boost your internet speed in line with your business requirements.
](http://www.T1Rex.com/)
Dedicated internet access used to be limited to a 1.5 Mbps T1 line or a 45 Mbps T3 line (DS3 bandwidth). Shared bandwidth services offer more choices, but their performance and availability can fluctuate. Additionally, they often have asymmetrical speeds, with download speeds significantly higher than upload speeds.
Dedicated options like T1 and T3 offer symmetrical bandwidth, consistent speed, and high availability backed by a Service Level Agreement (SLA). However, cost remains a concern, particularly if your needs exceed a T1 line but not a full T3 line.
While fractional line services offer a portion of a full line’s capacity at a reduced cost, they aren’t the most cost-effective per Mbps.
A better solution is bonded line service. Bonding combines multiple lines of the same type to increase bandwidth. For example, bonding two T1 lines provides 3 Mbps instead of 1.5 Mbps. Your router sees this as a single, larger bandwidth service, simplifying management.
While bonding offers incremental bandwidth increases, remember that bonded lines must be obtained from the same carrier. Additionally, costs increase proportionally with bandwidth; two T1 lines cost double a single line. This might be acceptable for doubling your speed compared to a tenfold price jump for a T3 line, but it becomes less appealing as you bond more lines.
You can bond up to eight T1 lines for 11 Mbps, but the cost might then near that of a 45 Mbps T3 line.
Ethernet over Copper (EoC) is another bonded service potentially offering more bandwidth for less. EoC uses multiple wire pairs, bonding 2, 4, 6, or 8 pairs for speed increases. Unlike T1, EoC offers a broader range of bandwidth choices. A 2-3 Mbps EoC connection might cost the same as a T1 line, with other options ranging from 5 Mbps to 45 Mbps. EoC’s cost per Mbps decreases with higher bandwidth levels.
However, EoC availability is limited due to its reliance on newer technology not present in all central offices. Distance also affects EoC speeds; proximity to your central office is crucial for optimal performance. Still, it may offer better speeds than bonded T1 at a lower cost.
If a reliable internet connection is essential for your business, explore the availability and pricing of bonded T1 and EoC dedicated internet access options.
title: 3 Mbps to 6 Mbps Bonded Internet Access

Cellular companies are promoting 3G wireless technology as the most advanced available. However, a faster technology called 4G is being gradually introduced across the country. This situation reflects the typical progression of technology, where an invention like wireless data service undergoes continuous advancements. Like early personal computers compared to today’s models, mobile data is following a similar path of growth.
Cellular carriers dominate wide-area mobile service due to their extensive network infrastructure. This infrastructure, originally built for phone calls, is now being cost-effectively used to provide data services. Starting with slow dial-up speeds, mobile data has advanced along two paths: CDMA, used by carriers like Verizon, and GSM, used by AT&T. These technologies have evolved into their third generation, known as 3G, and are accessible through various devices.
While 3G is still being improved, one carrier, Sprint, in partnership with Clearwire, is already launching 4G services. Their 4G technology, WiMAX, operates on different frequencies than 3G and offers faster download speeds. It is currently being offered as a home and business broadband internet service with mobile access through aircards.
WiMAX is already available in cities like Baltimore and Portland, with plans to expand to more cities by the end of 2010. Other carriers like AT&T and Verizon are also planning to introduce their 4G services based on LTE technology in the near future. This technology will coexist with 3G initially.
There is speculation that 3G might eventually be phased out as 4G technologies advance. The future points towards converged IP networks, suggesting that 4G networks carrying both VoIP and data services might become the new standard for wireless communication.
title: 4G Wireless Quietly Encroaching on 3G

M1, Singtel, and StarHub will discontinue 2G services in Singapore starting April 1, 2017. This includes 2G voice calls, messaging, and data services. Users with 3G and 4G devices will not be impacted.
Since the introduction of 2G service in 1994, mobile networks have progressed significantly. Singapore’s widespread 3G and 4G networks have resulted in high rates of smartphone ownership and use. The spectrum currently used for 2G will be reallocated to provide faster, more advanced 3G and 4G services to meet the growing consumer demand for mobile data and faster access speeds.
Mobile operators have been running outreach programs in recent years to encourage customers to switch to newer networks. Currently, the majority of mobile customers use 3G and 4G networks, with a tiny percentage still using 2G-only devices. Leading up to the 2G network shutdown, mobile operators will continue to communicate with impacted 2G users via a variety of appropriate channels, including SMS, calls, and posters at their retail locations.
A wide range of 3G and 4G handsets are offered at various price points to allow customers to upgrade to the latest networks. Existing SIM cards used with 2G-only handsets can be used in a 3G or 4G-compatible device to access 3G or 4G services.
title: 2G mobile phones will no longer be operational in Singapore starting from 1 April 2017

Wireless phone technologies have evolved significantly, progressing through different “generations” like members of a family. From the early days of pre-cellular mobile phones, the industry has witnessed the rise of analog cellular (1G), digital cellular (2G), and the emergence of 3G, with 4G on the horizon.
Like any family, the wireless phone sector has its share of triumphs, conflicts, and aspirations. While wireless internet technologies like WiFi operate under different standards, there’s potential for convergence, such as phones supporting both cellular and WiFi.
The wireless phone lineage can be traced back to post-World War II mobile telephone systems (0G), followed by the game-changing analog cellular (1G) in the 1980s. Digital cellular (2G) soon emerged, bringing standards like TDMA and CDMA, with Europe adopting GSM. Digital advancements enabled not only voice calls but also data services like internet access and messaging.
The need for faster data speeds led to the “G” classification. While 2G offered limited data speeds, the demand for data-intensive applications like internet browsing and video streaming spurred the development of 3G. Intermediate stages like 2.5G and 2.75G, including GPRS, emerged to bridge the gap.
3G technologies like EVDO are enabling phones to function as internet-connected computers, video phones, and television receivers. However, 3G will soon face competition from wireless VoIP services like WiFi, WiMAX, and the emerging 802.20 standard.
Looking ahead, 4G is poised to revolutionize mobile communication with data rates up to 20 Mbps, enabling high-quality video and fast downloads. With 4G phones expected to debut soon, the industry is already contemplating the possibilities of 5G.
For those interested in exploring further, resources on telephone history are available online. Additionally, platforms like Cell Phone Plans Finder offer competitive deals on cellular phone services, free phones, and cashback offers.

A significant battle is occurring in the telecommunications market between traditional T1 lines and the newer Ethernet over Copper (EoC) services. Both technologies aim to provide businesses with increased bandwidth at lower costs, catering to the growing reliance on internet connectivity, remote data center access, and cloud-based services.
The core of this competition lies in how these technologies utilize existing copper telephone wiring to deliver data services. While T1 lines have long been the standard, EoC presents a compelling alternative with potentially higher bandwidth at competitive prices.
T1 technology, initially designed for multiple voice calls on a single line, evolved to offer businesses internet connectivity and point-to-point data connections. Its strength lies in its maturity, widespread availability, and reliable 1.5 Mbps symmetrical bandwidth. For increased bandwidth needs, multiple T1 lines can be “bonded” to combine their speeds, though this approach lacks cost-effectiveness.
Ethernet over Copper, while also utilizing copper pairs, employs a different signal transmission method. This allows for significantly higher bandwidths, potentially reaching up to 50 Mbps. However, EoC’s effectiveness diminishes over distance, making it more suitable for businesses located closer to the central office and less viable in rural areas.
Businesses are increasingly choosing EoC over T1 due to its ability to deliver higher bandwidth without the cost and complexity of fiber optic installations. The cost advantage of EoC, often providing comparable pricing for significantly higher bandwidth, further adds to its appeal.
Currently, T1 and EoC remain closely matched in the market. T1 benefits from its widespread availability and established presence, while EoC attracts businesses seeking greater bandwidth at competitive rates.
The choice between T1 and EoC depends on each business’s specific needs and circumstances. Obtaining competitive quotes for both services is recommended to determine the optimal solution for a business’s bandwidth requirements. The competitive landscape ensures that attractive deals are now more readily available.
title: 3 Mbps T1 vs EoC Throwdown

The increasing popularity of cloud-based IT services might leave you wondering if you’re missing out. To help you decide, let’s explore the three primary cloud types and which applications are well-suited for cloud environments.
These days, it seems everyone is offering cloud services, primarily based on three architectures: public, private, and hybrid clouds.
The most common is the public cloud, a specialized data center owned and operated by a provider serving numerous paying customers concurrently. This type of data center, often highly secure and equipped with robust backup systems, is desirable but expensive to maintain.
Redundancy is crucial for cloud success, ensuring reliability through features like Service Level Agreements (SLAs) that guarantee uptime, restoration speed, and compensation for outages. These SLAs differentiate enterprise-grade providers from consumer-oriented services.
Redundancy encompasses duplicating critical components like servers, power sources, network infrastructure, and even staffing to ensure continuous operation.
Virtualization, another key aspect, optimizes resource use. Since many applications don’t fully utilize server capacity, virtualization allows multiple servers to operate as one, distributing workload dynamically.
This principle underpins the private cloud, where you build your own virtualized data center. You own, maintain, and control all resources, ideal for high-security or heavily regulated environments.
However, public clouds often offer better cost-effectiveness due to economies of scale. A newer option is a private cloud within a public data center, providing isolation without the investment and upkeep.
Lastly, the hybrid cloud combines public and private elements. You might use a public cloud for general applications and a private one for sensitive data, controlling information sharing between them.
Still unsure about cloud services? Seek expert advice and compare quotes for enterprise-level solutions.
title: 3 Types of Clouds You Should Know About

By: John Shepler
Previously thought to be an excessive amount of bandwidth only suitable for large telecom companies, 10 Gbps connections are quickly becoming the desired level of connectivity for businesses, local governments, medical facilities, content creators, and online retailers. The good news is this bandwidth level is now attainable at a reasonable cost.
Where Can I Get 10 Gbps Dedicated Internet? 10 Gigabit Ethernet service is now commonly available in most cities due to the widespread adoption of fiber optic infrastructure. Fiber optic lines are necessary to deliver the increased bandwidth required to support 4G LTE and 5G cell towers, replacing the older, slower T1 copper lines. Cable companies also utilize fiber lines for their core infrastructure, although the final connection to a cable modem still uses coaxial copper cable. Many cities are now installing fiber infrastructure as a public utility to bring service to all homes and businesses.
Once fiber optic cables are in place, establishing Gigabit and 10 Gigabit broadband connections is simple. Each fiber strand can handle 10 Gbps of bandwidth on just one channel. These same strands can also be configured to use multiple wavelengths of light to carry numerous Gigabit and 10 Gigabit services. A single fiber optic cable can hold anywhere from a few to over a hundred fiber strands. You can be confident that there is an abundance of 10 Gbps capacity readily available.
What 10 Gbps Service Options Are Available? The most popular service in demand is Dedicated Internet Access (DIA). Dedicated means you have exclusive use of your internet connection. All unused capacity on your connection is idle and at your disposal. You do not share bandwidth with other users.
Dedicated Internet Access provides the most consistent connection with the lowest latency (delay) for accessing the core of the internet. This is important if your company relies on remote servers in the cloud or uses colocation hosting. This type of connection is also important if you conduct business over the Internet and need your customers to have a smooth, responsive online experience.
There are also private, point-to-point 10 Gbps connections that can link your business locations or connect your company to a cloud service provider. This type of connection is a step above accessing services over the public internet. Private lines provide the lowest latency and the least amount of congestion. Having a dedicated private line makes your servers feel like they’re right down the hall, even if they’re geographically located across the country.
Cable internet providers now offer a shared bandwidth service that can achieve 10 Gbps download speeds using the DOCSIS 3.1 standard and will soon offer symmetrical 10 Gbps upload and download speeds using the DOCSIS 4.0 standard. While sharing an internet connection with other users can save money, connection speeds can fluctuate depending on network congestion and the number of active users.
What about wireless internet options? In some metropolitan areas, fixed wireless internet service delivered over microwave frequencies can provide bandwidth as high as 10 Gbps without the need for a wired connection. Installation times for fixed wireless are typically fast, sometimes only taking a few days or a week.
How Much Does 10 Gbps Internet Cost? Fiber optic service used to be very expensive, but prices have dropped in recent years due to increased competition among service providers and the economies of scale that come with more users subscribing to higher bandwidth services. If you haven’t priced out 10 Gbps internet service recently, you should get quotes from several providers. You may be surprised to find that several providers can now meet your needs.
title: 10 Gbps Dedicated Internet Access Availability

By Steve Endow
This article presents several helpful tips for using SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS) more efficiently.
A video demonstrating these tips is available.
Utilize the Object Explorer Details Window: Many users are unaware of the time-saving benefits offered by the Object Explorer Details window. Instead of solely relying on the Object Explorer pane for finding tables or stored procedures, pressing F7 to open the Details window significantly speeds up navigation and search. The video provides a demonstration of this feature. Double-Click Error Messages for Quick Navigation: When troubleshooting complex queries, double-clicking on an error message in SSMS will automatically direct you to the specific line of code causing the issue. Enable Line Numbers for Easy Reference: Displaying line numbers within the query window makes it simpler to pinpoint specific lines, especially when dealing with error messages or collaborative debugging. Effortlessly Transfer Query Results with Headers: When copying query results to Excel, using the “Copy with Headers” feature (right-click the blank square above row 1 or use CTRL+SHIFT+C) simplifies data transfer by automatically including column headers. Directly Save Query Results as Text Files: While less frequent, the option to save query results directly to a text file can be useful. SSMS provides comma or tab-delimited formatting for text output. However, it’s essential to note that the comma-delimited option might not create a fully CSV-compliant file, as it doesn’t automatically enclose text values containing commas within apostrophes. Improve SSMS Display Scaling on High-Resolution Screens: On high DPI displays, like 4K monitors or high-resolution laptops, SSMS might appear poorly scaled. This issue can be resolved by implementing the fixes detailed in a SQL Server Central post, as demonstrated in the video. The post provides a solution for adjusting the scaling to display appropriate icon sizes and readable text. Before the fix, icons may appear small, and text might seem squeezed.
After applying the fix, the scaling is improved, resulting in a better visual experience.
Hopefully, these tips offer valuable insights for enhancing productivity when working with SQL Server Management Studio.

As companies increasingly adopt cloud services and engage in data-heavy activities like video streaming and big data analysis, the demand for greater WAN bandwidth is on the rise. It’s becoming commonplace to see requests for 1,000 Mbps connections, often fulfilled by a 1 Gbps Ethernet or GigE point-to-point connection. Let’s explore the details and available choices for Gigabit Ethernet service.
Ethernet, the standard protocol for LANs, commonly operates at speeds of 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps, 1,000 Mbps, or 10 Gbps. Many network devices support multiple speeds, typically 10/100/1000 Mbps. It’s a natural progression to want to extend the LAN’s reach through the WAN to connect with another LAN. The key to avoiding bottlenecks that cause network congestion, while simultaneously preventing overspending on excessive WAN bandwidth, is to align your LAN and WAN speeds. This means using consistent LAN speeds and protocols.
Fortunately, the Metro Ethernet Forum (MEF), an industry group responsible for establishing vendor interoperability standards, has addressed this need. They’ve developed the necessary standards to enable the transportation of LAN Ethernet over WAN connections, known as Carrier Ethernet within the WAN environment.
This process begins and ends with a User Network Interface (UNI), a “port” installed at the user’s location(s) by the carrier or service provider. UNIs are designed to operate at standard LAN speeds: 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps, 1 Gbps, or 10 Gbps. However, this doesn’t restrict you to just these service speeds. The installed UNI determines the maximum bandwidth it can handle. The actual service speed is controlled by the carrier, limiting it to match your purchased bandwidth, which could be 20 Mbps, 75 Mbps, 450 Mbps, or another increment. This flexibility ensures you only pay for the bandwidth you actually require.
This setup offers a significant benefit. Not only are you not bound by a service that’s either insufficient or excessive for your needs, but the hardware is equipped to support the UNI’s port speed. The service provider can easily adjust the rate limiting via software, allowing for quick bandwidth increases. This means you can request a bandwidth upgrade and have it implemented potentially within hours or days. The carrier simply implements the change and modifies your billing accordingly. This streamlined approach contrasts sharply with traditional telecom services, which often necessitate on-site visits to install new equipment or wiring. As long as your UNI supports 1 Gbps, no hardware upgrades are needed until you exceed that speed.
The actual data transfer occurs over an Ethernet Virtual Connection (EVC), providing a point-to-point link between specific UNIs and preventing data exchange between sites that aren’t part of the same EVC. This widely used Ethernet point-to-point service is known as EPL or Ethernet Private Line, serving as a direct replacement for TDM private lines.
An interesting characteristic of Ethernet UNIs is their ability to manage multiple EVCs. This might seem unusual compared to typical telecom UNIs that connect physical wires and carry a single Point-to-Point (PTP) line service. You can think of each EVC as a separate private line. This delivery of multiple EVCs over a single UNI is referred to as EVPL or Ethernet Virtual Private Line service. A common topology is a hub-and-spoke configuration, where a central headquarters connects to various branch offices using EVPL. In this setup, only a single physical UNI is required at the headquarters to support all the private line spoke connections.
Is your business ready to embrace higher bandwidth WAN service? Explore the affordability of supporting 1 Gbps Point to Point Ethernet Connections using EPL and EVPL.

Gigabit internet speed is like the gold standard for high-speed business connections. But sometimes even 1 Gbps isn’t enough, and that’s when you need to consider upgrading to 10 Gigabit Internet.
Who Needs 10 Gbps Bandwidth? Most small businesses and almost all residential internet users don’t need this much speed. The bragging rights aren’t worth the high monthly fees. This level of bandwidth is meant for demanding applications that justify the cost.
Just a short while ago, 10 Gbps connections were only found in the core networks of telecommunication companies and the internet itself. But times have changed, and what was sufficient a decade ago is now barely adequate. Those 10 Gbps lines have become more widely available and easier for businesses to obtain.
Cloud services, colocation centers, and large corporations with thousands of connected employees need gigabit and 10 gigabit speeds, or even faster. High-tech companies and those using advanced tools might also require these higher speeds. Content providers absolutely need it. And hospitals and medical centers dealing with large imaging files can’t afford to wait for slow transfers.
What’s Involved In Acquiring 10 Gigabit Service? These high speeds are almost always delivered through fiber optic cable. Once fiber is installed, getting high speeds is just as easy as getting slower speeds. This is because fiber optic cable has a very high capacity for data transmission. The limiting factors are the number of fibers in the cable and the equipment at each end.
The first standard for high-speed fiber transmission was called SONET (Synchronous Optical Network) and was developed by telephone companies. You might have heard of OC-192, which is the 10 Gbps SONET Optical Carrier level. These days, most competitive networks, and even the telephone companies, are switching to Carrier Ethernet. Ethernet is directly compatible with almost all local area networks. It can also easily scale from 10 Mbps to 10 Gbps and beyond. What’s even more important for most businesses is that Carrier Ethernet (also called Ethernet over Fiber) is typically more readily available and less expensive than the older SONET technology.
Many regional, national, and international carriers now offer 10 Gig Ethernet access and point-to-point private lines. This means you might have several competitive offers to compare.
Why 10 Gbps Dedicated Internet Access? Imagine the internet as a vast electronic highway system with major interstates and countless on-ramps. Unless you’re a part of the internet’s core infrastructure, you’ll be connecting through one of these on-ramps, and their performance varies greatly.
The best internet performance comes from connecting to the network backbone through a high-tier provider using a dedicated connection. “Dedicated” means that you are the sole user of the bandwidth you’ve leased. This might seem like the standard, but most internet connections designed for consumers and smaller businesses are shared, not dedicated. By combining multiple customers on a single line, cable, satellite, and cellular wireless companies can offer affordable internet connections at reasonable speeds.
Another important factor is symmetric bandwidth. This means you have 10 Gbps for both uploading and downloading data. Those budget-friendly internet options usually have asymmetric bandwidth, with faster download speeds and slower upload speeds.
Bandwidth to Grow With Your Needs Since Carrier Ethernet is easily scalable, you can order the bandwidth you need now and upgrade it later as your business grows. With a 10 Gbps port, you can start with 1 Gbps, 5 Gbps, or another speed, paying only for what you use. As long as you have enough port speed, you can often upgrade with a simple phone call to your provider or even through your online account.
If you’re struggling with limited bandwidth but are worried that the solution is unavailable or too expensive, you might be pleasantly surprised. Go ahead and request competitive quotes from Dedicated Internet Access providers in your area.

MPLS networks have become a sought-after alternative to costly, proprietary WAN networks and the public internet, which can present performance and security challenges. Let’s explore what MPLS networks offer and the various ways to access them.
Imagine an MPLS network as a dedicated internet exclusively for businesses. Privately owned and operated, MPLS networks don’t provide services or connections for residential users, making them strictly business-to-business (B2B). Numerous service providers operate their own MPLS networks, offering regional, national, or international coverage. Some providers even specialize in connecting different MPLS networks, creating expansive “MPLS Mesh” networks.
MPLS often forms the core network for major service providers due to its adaptability. The underlying infrastructure typically consists of IP-based or SONET/SDH fiber optic service at speeds of 10 Gbps or higher, with many networks transitioning from 40 Gbps to the cutting-edge 100 Gbps. The defining feature of an MPLS network lies in its unique switching and routing system, which operates independently of specific protocols.
MPLS stands for Multi-Protocol Label Switching. “Multi-Protocol” signifies its ability to handle various data types, including Voice, Data, Video IP, SONET, T-Carrier, and more, simultaneously and without conflicts. “Label Switching” refers to the method of tagging each data packet entering the network. This tag guides the packet to its destination using an appropriate class of service and is removed upon exit, ensuring data integrity.
Think of MPLS networks as private high-speed highways, with access points acting as on and off-ramps. One significant advantage of using MPLS for long-distance data transmission is the simplicity it offers: businesses only need to focus on getting their data to and from the network. The network operator takes care of optimizing performance within the MPLS network, ensuring sufficient bandwidth with minimal latency, jitter, and packet loss.
EarthLink Business, for example, provides a nationwide, access-agnostic MPLS network with Service Level Agreements (SLAs) determined by Class of Service (CoS). They offer five distinct access technologies tailored to the needs of each business location, which can be mixed and matched while maintaining consistent CoS across a business’s network. Here’s a breakdown:
T1 Lines: The traditional and still prevalent access method, T1 lines are widely available over existing copper telephone wiring in most business locations. They offer symmetrical bandwidth of 1.5 Mbps, which can be increased by combining multiple lines. EarthLink boasts a four-hour mean time to repair (MTTR) for private T1 lines in case of disruptions.
DSL: Considered a budget-friendly alternative to T1, ADSL provides asymmetrical bandwidth with faster download than upload speeds. EarthLink is a pioneer in offering CoS traffic management over DSL, making it a viable option for business applications.
Ethernet over Copper (EoC) and Fiber (EoF): EoC and EoF are strong contenders against T1, DS3, and high-speed SONET fiber services. Ethernet aligns better with IP traffic compared to circuit-switched TDM (Time Division Multiplexing) technologies. Additionally, it offers scalability and cost-effectiveness per Mbps where available.
Wireless Access: Ideal for newly established locations needing quick setup or for affordable access where DSL is limited, wireless access provides flexibility. 3G and 4G cellular bandwidth, often available in remote areas, can offer speeds equal to or greater than T1 without requiring a landline. Fixed wireless microwave transmission provides even higher speeds and can serve as a practical alternative to fiber.
MPLS IPsec: EarthLink also offers this unique service. You might know IPsec, or IP Security, as a VPN technology used for secure internet connections. Its security stems from the 3DES encryption algorithm (168-bit), which is the financial industry standard for network-layer encryption. IPsec enables businesses to use local internet providers in remote areas while securely connecting to the corporate MPLS network.

Businesses often want greater internet bandwidth, lower telecommunication costs, or both. A relatively new service called 5x5 Ethernet might be the solution.
Ethernet services are a recent development. Before their rise in popularity, the best bandwidth options were T1 lines and fractional DS3 bandwidth. Fixed location wireless service has sometimes been available, but only for locations with a direct line of sight to their provider.
How do Ethernet services improve upon previous options? They frequently offer greater bandwidth at lower costs, even for low bandwidth services over copper.
Ethernet services are often categorized as Metro Ethernet, Carrier Ethernet, or by their bandwidth level. For example, 5x5 Mbps Ethernet denotes a dedicated speed of 5 Mbps for both uploads and downloads. This symmetrical bandwidth is standard for other telecom services but differs significantly from consumer-oriented services like DSL and Cable broadband.
Symmetrical bandwidth is crucial for transferring files between locations or backing up data to the cloud or a remote data center. In contrast, asymmetrical services, which have slower upload speeds, are designed for web browsing. This is because downloading web pages involves more data than sending commands to the server. While this also applies to video streaming, it doesn’t hold for video conferencing. Generally, any two-way online activity benefits from symmetrical bandwidth.
If your business currently relies on a T1 line or a combination of T1 lines, also known as fractional DS3 bandwidth, EoC (Ethernet over Copper) might be a more cost-effective solution. You’ll experience the same high quality of service expected from T1 or other telecom services but at a reduced price.
How much can you save? Suppose your business requires 5 Mbps symmetrical bandwidth for file transfers, video conferencing, or dedicated internet access. You could approximate this by combining three T1 lines to achieve 4.5 Mbps or four T1 lines for 6 Mbps. However, T-carrier service requires upgrades in 1.5 Mbps increments.
The issue with T1 lines is the lack of economies of scale. Two lines cost double a single line, and three lines, necessary for 4.5 Mbps, triple the price. Additionally, increasing bandwidth requires installing new lines, and there’s no cost-saving benefit to having additional capacity.
Comparatively, Ethernet pricing is more competitive than T1. Often, 2 Mbps Ethernet costs the same or less than a T1 line, and sometimes even 3 Mbps is available at that price. Your 5x5 Mbps Ethernet will likely cost roughly twice as much as a T1 line but deliver over three times the bandwidth. You might even find a better deal. The ambiguity in these figures arises from the fact that both T1 and Ethernet pricing depends heavily on the available services and competition at your business location.
It’s also important to note that Ethernet over Copper utilizes the same twisted-pair telephone wiring as T1 service. The technology leverages multiple pairs to increase bandwidth and is significantly more scalable than T-carrier services.
To optimize your setup, install an Ethernet port capable of handling your anticipated bandwidth needs in the foreseeable future. Then, order the bandwidth you require immediately. You should be able to upgrade your bandwidth quickly and effortlessly whenever needed by simply contacting your provider, without installation or construction delays.

content:
By: John Shepler
For about 150 years, twisted pair copper wiring has been the standard way to deliver telecom services. This includes everything from traditional phone service to T1 lines for internet access and private connections. However, copper wiring is becoming outdated. Even if you haven’t reached the bandwidth limits of copper yet, you might face issues if your local telephone company (which owns the copper lines) decides to stop service. So, what are the alternatives?
Alternatives to Copper Lines
Fiber optic cables are unmatched in terms of bandwidth. You can get speeds ranging from 10 Mbps to 10 Gbps, and even 100 Gbps in some areas. Hybrid Fiber Cable, also called cable broadband, can now deliver multi-gigabit speeds using the traditional coaxial cable.
This sounds promising, but what if you’re in an area without cable service and no fiber optic infrastructure nearby? Are you left without any service options?
5G Wireless: A Solution
Fifth-generation (5G) smartphones have mostly replaced the 4G LTE standard. 5G introduces new bands with increased bandwidth and lower latency, suitable for smart devices that make up the Internet of Things.
Another area where 5G is making significant progress is fixed wireless access (FWA). “Fixed” in FWA implies stationary applications like desktop computers, point-of-sale systems, or even your entire Local Area Network.
Wireless Internet Service Providers (WISPs) have been providing internet service to homes and businesses without access to wired or fiber internet. They are typically local and independent, using systems separate from cellular providers. If you have a WISP nearby, they can often provide the internet access you need.
What sets 5G apart from traditional WISPs is that it’s true cellular broadband, serving both stationary and mobile users. The same broadband you use on your phone can be delivered to an office, store, or home within range of a cell tower.
4G LTE initially drove the shift towards using cellular broadband instead of DSL, cable, or other wired services. When 4G LTE became widely available, it offered speeds comparable to standard broadband services and had enough capacity to serve many users simultaneously.
While 4G LTE remains a viable choice for various uses, 5G offers fiber-like speeds with low latency for applications requiring quick responses. Major cellular carriers are promoting 5G wireless as a competitor to cable internet in fixed locations. For businesses, 5G can often replace unavailable T1 lines or even DS3 bandwidth.
How to Get 5G FWA
You might have connected your phone to your computer or tablet via Bluetooth, using your phone as a personal internet hotspot. FWA takes this concept further. Instead of a phone, you install a 5G or 5G/4G LTE gateway, which could be a small device placed on your desk or a shelf. It may have an Ethernet port to connect to your router or might include a router and Wi-Fi hotspot. Some gateways have special antennas to enhance signal reception from the cell tower.
To explore 5G and 4G LTE options for your business, consider working with a bandwidth broker who represents multiple service providers. They can help you find a reliable connection with sufficient bandwidth for your business needs and suitable data limits. You might be surprised by the range of choices available, even in rural or underserved areas.
title: 5G Fixed Wireless Fills the Copper Gap
